name: Hexobarbital
summary: A short-acting barbiturate historically used as a sedative, hypnotic, and anesthetic agent.
description: Hexobarbital is a short-acting barbiturate that depresses the central nervous system through potentiation of GABAergic neurotransmission. It was historically used for induction of anesthesia, sedation, and treatment of insomnia, but is rarely used today due to safety concerns, high abuse potential, and the availability of safer alternatives.

sections.text: Enhances the activity of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, increasing chloride ion influx and causing CNS depression.

adult.oral: Historically 125–250 mg at bedtime for insomnia; anesthesia doses individualized
adult.iv: Doses for anesthesia induction varied; typically 100–200 mg slowly injected

sections.geriatric: Not recommended due to increased risk of adverse effects
sections.hepatic_impairment: Avoid or use with extreme caution

other: High risk of dependence and withdrawal
Avoid in patients with history of substance abuse

sections.pregnancy: Category D—risk of fetal harm; avoid unless absolutely necessary
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; not recommended
sections.geriatrics: High sensitivity to sedative effects; avoid use

sections.text: Gradual taper recommended if used for more than a few days to avoid withdrawal seizures.

items: Replaced in modern practice by safer sedative-hypnotics such as benzodiazepines and non-benzodiazepine agents.
Still used in some veterinary medicine contexts.

seo.title: Hexobarbital: Historical Short-Acting Barbiturate
seo.description: Hexobarbital is a short-acting barbiturate formerly used for insomnia, sedation, and anesthesia induction; largely discontinued due to safety concerns.
